abstract.text: Proton-lead and lead-proton data taking during 2013 has allowed LHCb to expand its physics program to heavy ion physics.

Results include the first forward measurement of Z production in proton-lead collisions as well as a measurement of the nuclear modification factor and forward-backward production of prompt and displaced J/ψ, ψ(2S) and Υ.
Angular particle correlations have also been measured for events of varying charged particle activity.

body_text.text: Introduction

Ultra-relativistic heavy-ion collisions are used to study the nuclear matter at high temperature and pressure where the formation of the Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP), a state of matter which consists of asymptotically free quarks and gluons, occurs.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Open heavy flavours and quarkonia are produced at the early stages of the collision and might interact with the deconfined medium, making them ideal probes of the QGP.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It was indeed predicted that in hot nuclear matter, charmonia are suppressed due to color screening of the heavy quarks potential [1].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Quarkonia can also be suppressed in absence of the QGP formation by Cold Nuclear Matter (CNM) effects.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Proton-Nucleus collisions (pA or Ap), which are interesting by themselves, are therefore essential to interpret Nucleus-Nucleus data in order to disentangle QGP effects from CNM effects in those collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The main CNM effects affecting quarkonium production include initial-state nuclear effects on the parton densities (shadowing) [2], the initial-state parton energy loss and final-state energy loss (coherent energy loss) [3], the finalstate absorption of the pre-resonant heavy quark pair by the spectator nucleons (nuclear absorption) albeit small at LHC [4] and the final-state interaction of the quarkonium with the produced medium (comovers) [5].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Proton-nucleus collisions are also useful for the determination of nuclear parton distribution functions (nPDF) [6].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The measurement of the Z electroweak boson in pA and Ap collisions in the LHCb acceptance permits to probe low x A values 1 (2 × 10 −4 -3 ×10 −3 ) in the forward case, and high x A value (0.2-1.0) in the backward case for an energy scale Q 2 = M 2 Z .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such a measurement (the first performed at the LHC in pA collisions) should offer large constraining power to nPDF fits especially at small x A .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Finally, two-particle angular correlations are interesting tools to probe collective effects in the dense environment of high-energy collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Thanks to the high particle density and multiplicities reached in pA collisions, of similar size to that of non central nucleus-nucleus collisions (AA), LHCb can investigate at forward rapidity the long-range correlation on the near side (ie the so-called ridge [7]) which was already observed in proton-proton (pp), proton-lead (pPb) and lead-lead (PbPb) collisions at mid-rapidity.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The LHCb detector and data taking
The LHCb detector is a single arm spectrometer in the forward region.
body_text.section: The LHCb detector and data taking

body_text.text: It is fully instrumented in its angular acceptance and covers the pseudo-rapidity range 2 < η < 5.
body_text.section: The LHCb detector and data taking

body_text.text: Initially designed for b-physics, the LHCb detector is becoming a general purpose detector by carrying out an extensive heavy-ion program (including pA, AA data taking in the collider mode and a rich fixed target program).
body_text.section: The LHCb detector and data taking

body_text.text: More details on the LHCb detector apparatus can be found in [8,9].

body_text.text: Nuclear effects are usually quantified by the nuclear modification factor R pA and the forward to backward ratio R FB .
body_text.section: The LHCb detector and data taking

body_text.text: Z production in pPb and Pbp
Z boson candidates have been reconstructed in the dimuon decay channel, in the fiducial region defined by 2.0 < η(μ ± ) < 4.5, p T (μ ± ) > 20 GeV/c and 60 < m μ + μ − < 120 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: A clean signal of 11 forward candidates in the forward region and 4 candidates in the backward region has been observed [18].
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: The cross section for Z production is found to be σ Z→μ + μ − = 13.5 +5.4 −4.0 (stat.) ± 1.2(syst.) nb in the forward direction and σ Z→μ + μ − = 10.7 +8.4 −5.1 (stat.) ± 1.0(syst.) nb in the backward direction.
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: The result in the forward region agrees with predictions from NNLO calculations using FEWZ [19] and the MSTW08 PDF set [20] with and without nuclear effects.
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: In the backward region, data are higher than theoretical calculations.
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: The forward-backward ratio has also been measured in the rapidity range 2.5 <| y CMS |< 4.0.
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: It is found to be lower than expectations with a 2.2σ deviation from one.
body_text.section: Z production in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: The present measurements have a limited statistical precision, preventing to conclude on the presence of nuclear effects.

body_text.text: Multi-particle correlations in pPb and Pbp

Two-particle angular correlations between prompt charged particles [21] in pPb collisions have been measured in the forward (backward) region in the rapidity ranges 1.5 < y < 4.4 (2.5 < −y < 5.4), respectively.
body_text.section: Multi-particle correlations in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: They were studied in event-activity classes, which are defined as fractions of the VELO hit-multiplicity distributions in a minimum bias sample.
body_text.section: Multi-particle correlations in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: In events with high event-activity a longrange correlation on the near side, the so-called ridge, is observed both in the forward and backward configurations, for 1 < p T < 2 GeV/c, while it is not observed in the 50-100% event-activity class (see Fig. 4 for the backward case).
body_text.section: Multi-particle correlations in pPb and Pbp

body_text.text: It was also observed that when probing identical absolute activity ranges in the pPb and Pbp configurations, the observed long-range correlations are compatible with each other (albeit there is a shift of one unit in rapidity coverage between both configurations).

body_text.text: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies
LHCb sucessfully participated in the pPb data taking in 2013.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: The production of prompt J/ψ, ψ(2S ), J/ψ and ψ(2S) from b and Υ has been measured in pPb collisions at √ s NN = 5 TeV.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: J/ψ from b and Υ(1S) are less affected by cold nuclear matter effects than prompt J/ψ which exhibits a stronger suppression.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: Prompt ψ(2S) seems even more suppressed than prompt J/ψ, especially in the backward region.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: Models of coherent energy loss with and without nuclear shadowing effects give a good description of the data, except for the production of ψ(2S) in the backward region.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: The prompt ψ(2S) data suggest that another CNM effect could be at play in the backward region.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: LHCb also performed the first measurement of Z production in pPb collisions at the LHC and the current analysis with limited statistical precision, will highly benefit from the larger statistics data sample which will be collected during run 2.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: Thanks to two-particle correlation analysis, LHCb observed for the first time the ridge in the forward region, in pPb collisions, thus complementing measurement at midrapidity from other experiments.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: The LHCb dectector will also collect for the first time PbPb data at √ s NN = 5 TeV at the end of 2015.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: LHCb will thus lead a rich physics program covering heavy flavour physics, electroweak physics, soft QCD physics and Quark Gluon Plasma studies.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: It is expected to collect L int ≈ 50-80 μb¯1 at the end of 2015.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: In addition, LHCb is in the unique position at the LHC to perform fixed target physics.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: Thanks to its System for Measuring Overlap with Gas (SMOG), initially used as luminosity monitor, noble gases can be injected inside the inner tracker of LHCb.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: With the proton and lead beams delivered by the LHC, and the various species of gas which can be injected in LHCb, a large number of fixed target configurations can be studied.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: LHCb already successfully collected proton-helium, proton-neon, proton-argon, lead-neon data and a lead-argon data taking is foreseen in parallel of the 2015 PbPb data taking.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: The highest center-of-mass energy which can be achieved in proton-gas collisions is √ s NN = 115 GeV while in lead-gas collision it is √ s NN = 72
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: GeV.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: Through its fixed target program, LHCb can bridge the gap from SPS to LHC with a single experiment.
body_text.section: Summary and prospects for heavy ion studies

body_text.text: LHCb is definitely becoming a truly general purpose detector in the forward region.
